author: @ManulaAlahakoon
text:
This is not going to work anymore. Because  Locations inside <loc> tags are not xml sites (Not end with .xml). The url inside it directly take us to the webpage related to that news but not to the related xml. So instead of using Sitemapindex struct to perform http.Get(Location) and tring to unmarshal that data to News struct , just directly Unmarshal the xml site in to News struct.  Try this ✌  package main  import ("fmt" "net/http" "io" "encoding/xml" ) /* type Sitemapindex struct { 	Locations []string `xml:"url>loc"` } */ type News struct { 	Titles []string `xml:"url>news>title"` 	Dates []string `xml:"url>news>publication_date"` 	Locations []string `xml:"url>loc"` }  type NewsMap struct { 	Date string 	Location string }  func main() { 	//var s Sitemapindex 	var n News 	news_map := make(map[string]NewsMap)  	resp, _ := http.Get("https://www.washingtonpost.com/news-world-sitemap.xml") 	bytes, _ := io.ReadAll(resp.Body) 	//resp.Body.Close() 	xml.Unmarshal(bytes, &n) 	          for idx,_ := range n.Locations{ 				news_map[n.Titles[idx]] = NewsMap{n.Dates[idx],n.Locations[idx]} 			}   	for id, data := range news_map { 		fmt.Println("
Title = ",id) 		fmt.Println("
Location = ",data.Location) 		fmt.Println("
Date = ",data.Date) 	} }

text: I am not getting any "body" in response from the Locations so my map is always empty. I wonder why is that? Anybody else facing the same issue? I guess WashingtonPost has upgraded its file design and now its not accessible easily that's why the response is empty. This is what I am trying to say -  ![CDATA[ Robinson scores 26 to lead Fresno St. past Air Force 65-40 ]] This is how the title and keywords are written in today's xml file rather that simply written like before. Can anyone tell us what is this? And does it make data inaccessible?

I need to put maybe like "" for keywords where it doesn't exist, but Unmarshal() isn't allowing that to happen. How do I fix this?

author: @vigneshmm2846
text: For those who getting  panic:  runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference  Use temp := strings.Split(Location, "\n") resp , _ := http.Get(temp[1])   root cause we get  invalid control character in URL

author: @dannydk6
text: For those getting segmentation faults,  add “Location = strings.TrimSpace(Location)” before ioutil.ReadAll

author: @guru0099
text: for those who are getting bytes variable empty with following error "runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference". First check the error in the response body by  resp, err := http.Get(location) fmt.Println(err).  IF the error is related to url i.e. "first path segment in url cannot contain colon", then import the "strings" library on the top and trim the Location variable which contains xml path like this -  Location = strings.TrimSpace(Location) Then w can use the above location variable to get response body in  resp, _ := http.Get(Location) The problem is related to extra spaces in xml locations
